Article Title: US and China reach “framework” deal to save TikTok from ban
Article Text:
Trump administration claims victory ahead of looming deadline

Questions remain over algorithm control and congressional approval





The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership, potentially averting a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent confirmed the preliminary deal during trade talks in Madrid, saying President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping will finalize the agreement in a Friday phone call.The framework would shift ownership of TikTok's US operations away from Chinese parent company ByteDance to American investors, addressing national security concerns that have dominated the app's future for years. While Bessent declined to reveal commercial terms, calling it a deal "between two private parties," he emphasized the agreement protects US security interests while preserving what Chinese negotiators consider the app's cultural characteristics.Trump celebrated the breakthrough on Truth Social, writing that "a deal was also reached on a 'certain' company that young people in our Country very much wanted to save."The announcement comes after months of negotiations and three deadline extensions since Trump took office, with the current ban scheduled to take effect Wednesday if no agreement is reached.Chinese trade negotiator Li Chenggang confirmed the two sides reached a "basic framework consensus" on resolving TikTok-related issues through cooperation. However, he warned the US against continued "suppression" of Chinese companies while seeking Chinese accommodation on American concerns.Critical details remain unresolved, including whether ByteDance will transfer control of TikTok's valuable recommendation algorithm that drives user engagement. Chinese officials previously expressed reluctance to export the algorithm technology, which Beijing considers strategically sensitive. Wang Jingtao from China's cyberspace regulator suggested the deal could involve licensing intellectual property rights rather than full transfer.Any final agreement may require approval from Congress, which passed bipartisan legislation in 2024 requiring ByteDance to divest TikTok or face a ban due to national security fears. The law, upheld by the Supreme Court, prohibits companies from "foreign adversary" countries from owning more than 20 percent of the platform.Industry analysts expect Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, a Trump ally whose company currently hosts TikTok's US data, to lead the American investor group. TikTok serves approximately 170 million US users, making it one of the most significant social media platforms in the country.
Article Summary: The United States and China announced they have reached a "framework" agreement to transfer TikTok to US-controlled ownership. The agreement could avert a ban of the popular social media app just days before a September 17 deadline. The framework would shift ownership of TikTok's US operations away from Chinese parent company ByteDance.

Article Title: Why Indian mobile numbers start with +91: The story behind the code
Article Text:
The ITU and global country codes

Why India received a short code

How +91 works in practice

Global calling: Country codes, including India’s neighbours



Pakistan – +92

Sri Lanka – +94

Bangladesh – +880

United States (US) – +1

United Kingdom (UK) – +44

Canada – +1

Russia – +7

Australia – +61

United Arab Emirates (UAE) – +971

Singapore – +65





Ever wondered why India’s phone numbers always start with +91? The answer lies in an international system managed by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), a United Nations agency responsible for global telecommunications. When country calling codes were first established, the ITU divided the world into geographic zones, assigning each region specific number ranges. India falls into the 9th zone, which covers South, Central, and West Asia as well as the Middle East. Within this system, India was given the two-digit code +91. The code ensures seamless international dialing and reflects India’s population size and economic significance.The International Telecommunication Union oversees the assignment of country codes worldwide. These codes standardize international dialing, allowing callers to reach any country reliably. By dividing the world into numbered zones, the ITU ensured that countries in the same region received codes starting with the same digit. India, in the 9th zone, was thus assigned a code beginning with 9, followed by a unique number, making its code +91.Factors like population size and economic importance influenced the length of country codes. Heavily populated and economically significant nations were given shorter codes to simplify dialing. India, being one of the world’s largest countries by both population and economic activity, received a concise two-digit code, making international communication more convenient.When dialing internationally, the +91 prefix signals that the call is directed to India. This is followed by the local area code and the subscriber number. The system works uniformly for both mobile and landline numbers, ensuring that anyone worldwide can recognize and call Indian numbers using the same standardized format.India’s +91 country code reflects both its regional placement in the ITU’s 9th zone and its global significance. By providing a short, standardized code, the ITU made international dialing simpler, allowing seamless communication with India from anywhere in the world. The +91 prefix is now a universal identifier for Indian phone numbers.
Article Summary: The International Telecommunication Union oversees the assignment of country codes worldwide. India falls into the 9th zone, which covers South, Central, and West Asia. Within this system, India was given the two-digit code +91. The code ensures seamless international dialing and reflects India’s population size and economic significance.

Article Title: US Senate AI hearing: Why Parents are demanding stronger safeguards for children using chatbots
Article Text:
Parental testimonies highlight AI risks

OpenAI and Meta’s response

Federal scrutiny and FTC inquiry



Proposed legislation: The CHAT Act



Growing demand for AI accountability





Parents whose children died or were hospitalized following interactions with AI chatbots urged Congress on September 16, 2025, to introduce stricter regulations to protect minors. At a Senate hearing convened by Senator Josh Hawley, parents called for laws prohibiting chatbots from engaging in romantic or sensual conversations with children, mandating age verification, requiring rigorous safety testing, and implementing crisis response protocols. Among those testifying were Matthew Raine, who sued OpenAI after his son’s suicide was allegedly linked to ChatGPT, and Megan Garcia, who filed a lawsuit against Character.AI. The hearing also spotlighted Meta Platforms over concerns about inappropriate chatbot conversations with minors, though the company declined to testify.Matthew Raine shared his son Adam’s tragic story, emphasizing that chatbots can provide harmful guidance during vulnerable moments. “Chatbots need some sense of morality built into them,” Raine said, describing how ChatGPT gave his son detailed self-harm instructions.Megan Garcia also testified, recounting her son Sewell’s interactions with Character.AI and advocating for legislation that prevents companies from testing AI products on children. Another mother from Texas, who appeared under a pseudonym, described her child’s hospitalization following chatbot interactions. These testimonies underscore concerns that AI chatbots, if inadequately regulated, can pose serious mental health risks to minors.OpenAI acknowledged that ChatGPT safeguards may become less reliable over extended interactions and announced plans to estimate user ages to direct children toward safer chatbot versions. Meanwhile, Meta Platforms, invited to testify, declined to appear. Hawley’s office noted prior internal reports indicating the company’s chatbots had engaged children in romantic or sensual conversations, which Meta disputes and says have been addressed. These developments highlight ongoing questions about AI companies’ accountability and safety measures for younger users.In addition to Senate hearings, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has launched a broad inquiry into AI companies including OpenAI, Character.AI, Meta, Google, Snap, and xAI. The FTC aims to evaluate the potential risks to children and teens, assess safety measures, and examine data handling practices. The agency emphasizes balancing innovation with child protection, scrutinizing chatbot design, crisis management capabilities, and possible mental health impacts on minors.Lawmakers introduced the Children Harmed by AI Technology (CHAT) Act, proposing measures to safeguard minors. The bill seeks to require parental consent for chatbot use, ban sexually explicit interactions, mandate real-time alerts for suicidal ideation, enforce privacy protections for age verification data, and require clear warnings distinguishing AI responses from human communication. The legislation would also authorize federal enforcement to ensure compliance, holding AI companies accountable for child safety.The Senate hearing reflects mounting pressure on AI developers to implement comprehensive safeguards. Parents, lawmakers, and regulatory agencies are advocating for stronger oversight to prevent further harm to children. With lawsuits ongoing and investigations underway, the hearing underscores the urgent need for policies that protect vulnerable users while allowing AI innovation to continue responsibly. As technology advances rapidly, lawmakers and companies alike face mounting pressure to create AI systems that are both innovative and inherently safe for younger users.
Article Summary: Parents whose children died or were hospitalized following interactions with AI chatbots urged Congress to introduce stricter regulations to protect minors. At a Senate hearing convened by Senator Josh Hawley, parents called for laws prohibiting chatbots from engaging in romantic or sensual conversations with children. The hearing also spotlighted Meta Platforms over concerns about inappropriate chatbot conversations with minors.

Article Title: How a coffee app that beat Starbucks in China is now brewing a US challenge
Article Text:
How Luckin Coffee’s app-first strategy is helping



Starbucks CEO praises app-only Luckin Coffee





Luckin Coffee, the Chinese coffee chain that overtook Starbucks as the country’s largest coffee chain, is now aiming for the US market with an app-driven business model. According to a DailyMail report, the company opened its first American store in New York in May this year and has already expanded to five different locations across the city. Unlike traditional cafés, Luckin shops operate without cashiers — all orders must be placed through the brand’s mobile app, and customers collect their drinks directly from counters.Luckin Coffee’s appeal comes from its heavy reliance on digital engagement. Customers are lured with steep discounts, often 30% to 50% off menu prices, delivered through coupons and codes in the app. The company has also used giveaways, such as free tote bags and drinks under $1, to attract students and young professionals.This aggressive pricing mirrors the tactics that helped Luckin Coffee dethrone Starbucks in China, where it built a loyal base of young urban consumers through low prices and social media promotions, including TikTok.However experts want that Luckin Coffee’s US expansion may face hurdles as the business model is not sustainable in the long term. The DailyMail report quotes Bernstein US restaurant equity research analyst Danilo Gargiulo who said “In the case of Luckin, the idea is I want to grow in awareness”.“They want to make sure that the brand gets recognized on a national basis, even though at the beginning, this means that I might need to be suffering from some smaller losses on a per store basis,” he added.Starbucks, he said on the other hand, “is always striving to be profitable on a single occasion... Usually, trying to target a minimum of 15 percent margin per store is our estimation”.As quoted in a Business Insider report, Starbucks CEO Brian Niccol said “They've done an interesting job on how they've turned the app into the only way you can interact with that business”. “It's a different approach. I don't think it's the right approach for us,” he added."The one thing that they probably have done a nice job of is just an unbelievable pace of product innovation," Niccol said. "It sets the tone for, 'Hey, we cannot be complacent on flavors and drink combinations.'"
Article Summary: Luckin Coffee opened its first American store in New York in May this year. Unlike traditional cafés, Luckin shops operate without cashiers. All orders must be placed through the brand’s mobile app. Customers are lured with steep discounts, often 30% to 50% off menu prices.

Article Title: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy says company culture needs a reset: ‘As you get larger, it’s really easy to…’
Article Text:
Andy Jassy, CEO of Amazon

Steps Amazon has taken till now to cut bureaucracy



Amazon’s shrinking workforce







Amazon CEO Andy Jassy recently explained what and how the e-commerce company is working to improve the company’s culture. Speaking at Amazon ’s annual conference for third-party sellers in Seattle (via CNBC), Jassy said that "bureaucracy is really anathema to startups and to entrepreneurial organizations" and that he is working to root out bureaucracy and flatten the organisation as part of his effort to reset its culture and boost innovation.“I would say bureaucracy is really anathema to startups and to entrepreneurial organizations. As you get larger, it’s really easy to accumulate bureaucracy, a lot of bureaucracy that you may not see,” Jassy said as quoted in the CNBC report.In September last year, Amazon CEO Andy Jassy set a goal to flatten organizations across Amazon. He then announced to reintroduce a five day work week at the company, from the previous three days. Jassy also called for the e-commerce giant to increase worker-to-manager ratio by at least 15% by the end of the first quarter of 2025.In the same year, Andy Jassy also announced the creation of a “no bureaucracy email alias”-- an initiative aimed to help employees flag unnecessary processes or excessive rules at the company. As part of this, Jassy said it has received about 1,500 emails in the last one year. Amazon, he said has changed about 455 processes based on that feedback.The e-commerce giant has laid off more than 27,000 employees since 2022. In an internal memo sent to employees earlier this year, Andy Jassy said that artificial intelligence will reduce the company's corporate workforce over the next few years as it integrates more AI tools and agents across its operations."We will need fewer people doing some of the jobs that are being done today, and more people doing other types of jobs," Jassy wrote in an internal memo. "It's hard to know exactly where this nets out over time, but in the next few years, we expect that this will reduce our total corporate workforce as we get efficiency gains from using AI extensively across the company."

Speaking at Amazon ’s annual conference for third-party sellers in Seattle, Jassy said that "bureaucracy is really anathema to startups and to entrepreneurial organizations"

Elon Musk’s relentless grind, driving Tesla, Neuralink, and Optimus





Elon Musk offers the world a stark glimpse into his extreme daily schedule: “I go to sleep, I wake up, I work, go to sleep, wake up, work, do that seven days a week.” This relentless routine drives his involvement in multiple high-profile ventures, from Tesla’s groundbreaking electric vehicles and Neuralink’s medical breakthroughs to the upcoming rollout of the Optimus humanoid robot. Behind the scenes, Musk’s hands-on involvement, from product development to operational strategy, reflects the unyielding energy suggested by his “sleep, wake up, work” mantra.The same intense focus extends to Neuralink, where Musk oversees progress on brain-computer interfaces. The development pace reflects Musk’s hands-on leadership style and the extreme hours he invests, showing how his personal grind directly shapes technological progress in robotics.While Musk’s routine produces results, experts warn of the dangers. Chronic overwork can lead to burnout, impaired judgment, and serious health consequences. Critics argue that glorifying such extreme schedules risks normalizing workaholism and unrealistic expectations in corporate culture. Supporters counter that Musk’s approach is a personal choice, emphasizing the sacrifices sometimes required to operate at the top tier of innovation.Elon Musk’s “sleep, wake up, work” lifestyle is inseparable from the successes of Tesla, Neuralink, and Optimus. Article Title: Google CEO Sundar Pichai breaks silence on Microsoft, Meta 'poaching' Google DeepMind employees: I do know individual cases can ...

Sundar Pichai, CEO, Google

Retention metrics “Healthy,” says Pichai



The cost of staying competitive







With the growing concerns over an escalating talent war in the artificial intelligence segment, Google CEO Sundar Pichai has publicly addresses the issue of employee poaching, specifically from Google DeepMind, the company’s AI research division. As reported by Business Insider, speaking at Alphabet’s Q2 earnings call, Pichai acknowledged the growing competition from rivals like Microsoft, Meta and also from emerging players such as OpenAI. All of these companies have aggressively recruited AI experts and that to with multimillion-dollar compensation packages.“I do know individual cases can make headlines,” Pichai said, referring to recent high-profile departures. “But when we look at numbers deeply, I think we are doing well through this moment.”As reported by Business Insider, Google CEO remains confident of Google’s internal metrics despite the ongoing talent drain. “We continue to look at both our retention metrics, as well as the new talent coming in, and both are healthy,” he stated. Google declined to share specific figures when asked by Business Insider.Pichai’s comments come at a time when Meta has launched its ‘superintelligence’ division and has already poached many former Google employees including Pei Sun, the researcher who contributed to Google’s Gemini AI assistant and Waymo self-driving technology.According to Business Insider, analysts such as Bernstein’s Mark Shmulik, raised concerns about the increasing costs of staying ahead on the race of AI innovation. A recent report by SignalFire revealed that researchers are 11 times more likely to leave Google for Anthropic than the reverse — a stark indicator of shifting industry dynamics.Pichai stressed on the fact that retaining the top talent is not all about offering huge compensation packages. “Access to compute is super important,” he said, referencing Google’s investment in cutting-edge chips and infrastructure. “Researchers want to be at the frontier driving progress… the mission and how state-of-the-art the work is matters.”
Article Summary: Google CEO Sundar Pichai has publicly addressed the issue of employee poaching, specifically from Google DeepMind, the company’s AI research division. “We continue to look at both our retention metrics, as well as the new talent coming in, and both are healthy,” he stated.

What the US entertainment companies said in the lawsuit



“MiniMax’s bootlegging business model and defiance of US copyright law are not only an attack on Plaintiffs and the hard-working creative community that brings the magic of movies to life, but are also a broader threat to the American motion picture industry.”

“MiniMax completely disregards U.S. copyright law and treats Plaintiffs’ valuable copyrighted characters like its own. MiniMax’s copyright infringement is willful and brazen. Given the rapid advancement in technology in the AI video generation field ... it is only a matter of time until Hailuo AI can generate unauthorized, infringing videos featuring Plaintiffs’ copyrighted characters that are substantially longer, and even eventually the same duration as a movie or television program,”

Google’s New AI Is BANANAS: How To Use Gemini Nano Banana





Walt Disney Co., Universal Pictures, and Warner Bros. Discovery have sued Chinese AI company MiniMax. The US-based entertainment companies have alleged that the service offered by the AI startup, which is also known as one of China’s ‘Six Tigers’, generates copyrighted characters without permission. Alongside Zhipu AI, Moonshot AI, Baichuan Intelligence, StepFun, and 01.AI, Minimax is seen as part of the country’s most prominent AI firms. These companies are staffed with talent that includes former employees of major U.S. and Chinese tech giants, such as Google and Huawei.According to a report by The LA Times, the lawsuit claims MiniMax's AI has created iconic characters, including Darth Vader, the Minions, and Wonder Woman. The entertainment studios are seeking damages of up to $150,000 for each infringed work, along with attorney fees and costs. They have also requested that MiniMax be stopped from any further infringement.In their complaint (as seen by LA Times), filed in the US District Court in Los Angeles, the companies said:The entertainment companies asked that MiniMax be barred from further infringement and are seeking damages of up to $150,000 per infringed work, along with attorney fees and costs.According to the lawsuit, Shanghai-based MiniMax operates a service called Hailuo AI, marketed as a “Hollywood studio in your pocket.” The platform allegedly featured characters such as the Joker and Groot in its ads without the studios’ consent.The document states that users can enter a text prompt requesting characters like “Star Wars’” Yoda or DC Comics’ Superman, and Hailuo AI can generate high-quality, downloadable images or video of them.the lawsuit added.This marks the latest wave of copyright lawsuits filed by major studios against AI companies over intellectual property issues. In June, Disney and Universal Pictures sued AI firm Midjourney for copyright infringement, and earlier this month, Warner Bros. Discovery also brought a lawsuit against Midjourney.

Article Title: How and why Microsoft’s $1 billion bet on ChatGPT-maker OpenAI in 2019 may be best investment in tech history
Article Text:
ChatGPT became the deciding factor

OpenAI recently announced plans to restructure into a for-profit public benefit corporation, a move that will allow it to issue traditional stock to investors. With this change, according to analysts, Microsoft is set to receive a new equity stake in OpenAI that could be worth at least $150 billion. This would be a remarkable return on Microsoft’s total investment of approximately $13 billion – suggesting that bet is shaping up to be one of the most successful investments in the history of technology.According to a report by Business Insider, the potential return rivals some of the most famous technology acquisitions. Google's purchase of YouTube for $1.65 billion in 2006 and Facebook's acquisition of Instagram for $1 billion in 2012 are both now worth hundreds of billions.However, there is a huge difference. Google’s and Meta’s investments took more than a decade to mature, while Microsoft's return on its OpenAI investments has grown at a much faster pace.The original partnership between Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella, CTO Kevin Scott, and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman was unusual, involving profit-sharing units in what was then a charity. As part of the deal, OpenAI received credits to use Microsoft's Azure cloud service to train and operate the large AI models that power ChatGPT.Following the launch of ChatGPT and its growth, OpenAI required more money to support its operations. The startup’s unusual corporate structure presented challenges in raising capital from new investors who sought traditional equity stakes. This pressure led to a renegotiation of the partnership with Microsoft, a process that has been described as acrimonious but is now nearing a resolution.The outcome appears to be a win-win: Microsoft stands to gain a massive equity stake, and OpenAI can now issue traditional stock to raise more funding.Given OpenAI’s current valuation of $500 billion from a new funding round, a 30% stake would be worth $150 billion, and a 33% stake would be worth even more.
